characters: FROM THE VERY START, THAT YOU
IF I GIVE MY HEART TO YOU
DON'T YOU THINK WE SHOULD TALK ABOUT
I'M GONNA WASH THAT MAN RIGHT
WOULD LOVE ME MORE THAN HIM
NO, I DON'T WANT TO TALK ABOUT ITI
AND I DON'T WANT TO TALK ABOUT IT
AND I FOUND THAT LOVE WAS MORE
I DON'T WANT A NICE RICE PUDDING
I THINK WE SHOULD TALK ABOUT IT
I WANT TO TALK ABOUT ITII
I'M GIVING MY CHILD HER BIRTHDAY
ON FAITH AND GEORGE AND SHERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stairway too formal for this house; light catching the burnished steps. A man comes into view. In his late thirties, bulky, muscular; a dynamic, almost compulsive face, a specially sharp edge now to the rough features. His name is GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Soundlessly moving down the stairway into the hall. He wears evening trousers, dress shirt, an untied black tie.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Books line the walls: a desk, a corkboard, autographed pictures of sports figures; a hot plate and teapot, a cedar file and a good chair. Goerge stares at the desk, then sits. He looks into space for a moment, his head nods into his hands. George sud- denly looks up, blinks: his eyes brim with tears; he sobs.. HOLD on George.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: A woman sits before a mirror, ~ FAITH, young for her early thirties: woman, child and mother in one and in conflict; but the best of each, puckish, feisty, a natural unworked-for beauty. PULL BACK from Faith to reveal her four children looking at her in the mirror. MOLLY, 7; MARIANNE, 10; JILL, 12; SHERRY, 13. Sherry dis- tanced from the rest; at the brink of womanhood, a school skirt, a scarf falling around her young breasts. The girls lean towards their mother, intent on her dressi up preparations. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A HAND 4
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal it is George's hand on the telephone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ... it won't be easy, in the middle of all those people and all I'1l be doi: is thinking about you. Rafter a@ moment) Maybe I'll win, that would help. A VOICE comes back through the phone; clean, seductive, soothing. Her name is SANDY.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'll win, you're a winner.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Molly, Faith's youngest child, is mimicking her mother, smearing her lips with lipstick; contortions of the mouth

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But even if I win, I lose, if you know what I mean? .

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Forget us tonight, just try to have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: it's been so long since I've had a good time, I wonder if I still know how... : cur To:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY JILL
dialogues.text: Yeah! Yeah! No no, me first --

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Forget it, Mom, you'll never get to the party.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, you guys are going to keep me here all night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Aw, c'm'on, Mom, just a little -- Faith swivels towards Molly.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Open wide. Molly parts her lips.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Not your mouth, darling, your eyes. Molly rolls her eyes.upwards. The girls squeeze close, everyone arching their eyebrows, fluttering their eye- lashes. Except Sherry, who drifts towards the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE TABLE
dialogues.text: Sherry picks up the extension, but holds the cradle down, now carefully lifts her finger, MOVE IN on Sherry's face.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . Where are you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Home! I thought you'd stopped for gas. I thought you were at the Texaco. Get off the phone, for God's sake --

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Her eyes beautifully outlined now like a pre-Raphaelite painting. Faith beams at her handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Faith now applying a touch of eyeliner, the children opening their eyes wide in support, Faith checks the eyeliner in the mirror. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I love it. Molly, entranced with her mother's pencil, steals it to try some eyeliner for herself. Faith, who has been busy with fingertip to eye, now reaches for the pencil, but it is not there. She slaps the boudoir tabletop in search of it, spies Molly.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hey, Moll, give us a break. Jill snatches the pencil away from Molly, hands it over to her mother. Molly's face instantly a pudding of de- spair. Faith notices.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Molly) Come here, let me show you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (at the mirror) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Like a hooker.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So do you! (grabbing Faith) Do I look like a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, you look beautiful, you don't look anything like a hooker.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to Jill) See, I don't look anything like a hooker! Faith laughs, hugs Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to Faith) What's a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY 10
dialogues.text: y George coming up, Sherry going down. They meet.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You're off the phone? George pauses.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I asked you if you were off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was just talking to Jim. George continues up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Jim, huh? Is that why you whispered? George turns around. —~ GEORGE Yeah, that's why I whispered. But Sherry hasn't heard his reply, she has already turned to go downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (calling up to George) You better hurry! Mom looks terrific!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND GEORGE'S BEDROOM LL
dialogues.text: George walks in.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: as Faith turns around face him. A moment: George is pleased by his wife's appearance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You look really nice.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y CONTINUED: 1l

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You look really pretty.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You seem surprised. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, forget it. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Is the dress okay?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. (squints at Faith's dress) It's the one you wore last year, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why, does it still have wine on it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wine?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The wine you spilled when Peter Atchison won instead of you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You always remember the wrong things, George exits. Sherry returns, easing into the room, picki at a container of yogurt with a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Sherry) I look all right?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You look fabulous, Mom, Sherry offers her mother a spoonful of yogurt. But Faith, still at the mirror, ignores her, she is shaking her head Faith is re-examining her dress. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ps FAITH It needs a thing to gather it up at the waist.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: No, Mom, leave it like that, all smooth,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I need a thing. Where's the silk rope that goes with my linen dress -- I saw it somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Between the big trees.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Where?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: The dryer broke when it was Molly's turn to do the laundry. She used it to hang out the wash. ~~ Faith sighs. She catches a glimpse of Sherry in the co ner of the mirror, Sherry is wearing a hide-and-fringe Davy Crockett belt. Faith zeroes in on the belt; instantly Sherry and Faith get the same idea.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (taking off her belt) Try it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Now don't go wearing Sherry's old belt, Mom -- Sherry ignores her, helping Faith do the belt around her waist. Now everyone checks Faith in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: It looks great. ——~ (CONTINUED)  y

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Real great, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Pret-tee. Faith does look charming, Sherry's scarf a touch which lifts her to the edge of beauty; Faith's smile takes her the rest of the way.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: ... Now everybody, get ready for bed -- Molly, you go to bed --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Mom -- you promised --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I did not -- the show doesn't go on 'til 11:30 -- you've got school --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You promised. You promised! I had to go to bed last year. Molly starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You didn't promise. Make her go to bed, Mom -- she'll drive us crazy. Molly is desperate, inconsolable. Faith leans over Molly. Faith smiles, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: All ripht. you can stay up -- you can all stay up -- Molly hugs her mother with one hand, gives Jill the finge with the other. Jill stomps out, furious. Sherry wraps Faith's jacket around her mother, pulls her head close, whispers to Faith.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: That was her on the phone with him. The SOUNDS in the b.g, of the jabbering children suddenly drop out. Faith and Sherry exchange a deep look. The SOUNDS suddenly return now, and Faith instantly comes back to life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (exiting) Be good! Get ready for bed! Brush our teeth! Sherry, do your jomework! -- Marianne, don't forget your worm medicinel --

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I hate it, it makes my B.M.'s all red.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (out the door) Good, they're coming out! Jill, find your ballet slippers -- you've got class tomorrow! Molly, if you're going to stay up, clean out your closet! Throw all that horrible underwear in the wash and, Sherry, if the plumber calls, tell him there's a leak in the washing machine! Faith hurries out as the children run to catch up with he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George at the wheel, Jill reaching through the window to kiss her father.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (tousling George's head) I love your haircut.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Your bow tie's too skinny.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, it's not. It belonged to Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (yanking) It's a real one ~- it's not a clip-on.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I tied it myself. Faith appears, she hurries towards the car, opens the pas senger side. Jill and Molly are hanging on the car on the driver's side. George rolls down the window to kiss them. Upstairs, Sherry pensively watches the car drive off.

dialogues.speaker: BAY BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The lights of San Francisco reflecting over the water, through the iridescent dusk; George's car streaking across the picture postcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLANG of a cable car bell. The cable car fills then leaves the frame, revealing Goerge's car right behind, he has been trying to pass.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Goddam things. 1 could shoot Tony Bennett. George turns, accelerates sharply up a steep hill.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This city could die from quaint. Faith stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That was a joke. Faith ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not funny, huh? Faith blinks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten you'd stopped laughing. Faith doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds milling about the approach to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you going to help me through this tonight, or not? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Jeezus, look at all these people. I knew we should have washed the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotlights, a red carpet. A DOORMAN opens George's door with a flourish.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quickly) Faith, are you with me?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's your night, George. George jumps out, runs around to help Faith out, takes her arm as PHOTOGRAPHERS move in. He Plunges forward, protecting Faith through the melee, right past the Photog raphers who, not recognizing them, move on to the next arrivals.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Try to smile, will you? There's Willard. : WILLARD approaches, a man in his sixties, a publishing type in a velvet jacket and Peal slippers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Hello, George, hello, Faith. Willard kisses Faith.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where's Isabel?

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: She's inside already, SCOTT, an eager young man, rushes up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Okay, George, this is Scott Gruber from Manning Publicity.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: {all aglow) Congratulations on a super book, Mr. Dunlap --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is all this, Willard? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: A little glamor, George.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: A little icing on the cake. A little pizzazz, a little hype. Books are show biz, too. And we do have the winner here. He puts his arm around George, leading him a step ahead of Faith, Scott turns around.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don't count your chickens, he hasn't won yet.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: This must be the missus?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Faith Dunlap, yes. Scott Scott Gruber, publicity. Love your belt] , Faith shakes his hand hard.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Now here's how it goes --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here's how what goes?

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Patience, George. scott I'd like you to turn around, Mr. Dunlap -- (turns George around) Can I call you George? -- go back to the head of the carpet, George, do the walk-in again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Take it from the top. You'll see, you're going to love it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: You heard him, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But we're already in... it's so phony.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Follow me please. People are pulling and pushing. Faith, a yard behind, tries to catch up. George turns to her, grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: For God's sake, smile. Faith bares all her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (through the teeth) I'm smiling, I'm smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCOTT
dialogues.text: Leading George and Faith past the snapping Photographers again, REPORTERS scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: (to the Photographers) George Dunlap, 'The Court Game,’ Willoughby House. That's Dun-lap. Dunlap with an ‘a.' The Photographers chiming "Right this way, Mr. Dunlap. Over here, Mr. Dunlap."

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Faith gets separated for the moment from George. A Photo team is checking their captions.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (to Photographer) And you are -- ?

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: (prompting impatiently) "George Dunlap and friend.'

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm not his friend! I'm his wife!

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: (pushing past) Huh? Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening gowns and black ties, banquet tables, a dais, a giant banner, “INTERNATIONAL BOOK AWARDS". Scattered about are publishers and editors with three-piece dinner jackets, Phi Beta Kappa keys, lapels dotted with Legion of Honor rosettes; trendy young women from the paperbacks MOVE IN on a table close to the dais, George and Faith seated between Willard and his wife, ISABEL. Isabel is a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (to Faith) Every time George comes to New York, all he can talk about is you and the children -- when am I ever going to see these wonderful children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have some pictures. (starts fishing helplessly in her crowded bag) I know they're here somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Oh don't bother, dear, I can just imagine how fabulous they are. (consults her program) When is non-fiction anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE AND FAITH'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: A Master of Ceremonies, a Peter Ustinov/Gore Vidal type is leading the applause for a winner who is just walking away with his award, Sherry, Jill, Marianne and Molly are perched in front of their set, watching.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Where are they? I still don't see them. Molly gets up surreptitiously.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: No more Shredded Wheat, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It's Cap'n Crunch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I don't care what it is. No more sugar and no more cream -- you know what Mommy says --

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh I think I saw them!... Oh no, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: But I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Suck an Acerola.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Having left the nether world of fiction, we arrive at the cool, clear daylight of fact... SHERRY So Shut up everybody! Here it is!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV
dialogues.text: The Emcee is presented with a card. He reads:

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . and the winner is -- for 'The Court Game' -- George Dunlap,

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: jumping up and down, beside themselves with joy.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV
dialogues.text: Everybody standing up and applauding, except for George. He looks bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: stil all excited as George rises unsteadily from his table.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Dad-dee! Dad-dee!

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Where's Mom -- why doesn't she straighten his tie?

dialogues.speaker: BANQUET HALL
dialogues.text: The Emcee hands George a statue and a check. The audience all stand up now and applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of faces. The whole place a nervous blur.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Admiring his statue, his hands trembling slightly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (turning now to address the gathering) » I never thought "The Court Game’ would be so good to me -- and my family...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: _ 'His family'! The kids raise each other's arms in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Take a bow, folks! But Molly does not join in, she is still squinting at the Tv.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Daddy looks fat.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: It's his suit.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (correcting) His tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I think he rented it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why is he smiling so much?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I think he's nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And I would also like to share this award with my friend, my helpmate... that most thankless of occupations, Writer's Wife, I mean my wife -- A portable TV camera whips around and zooms in on Faith.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A lady so aptly named -- Faith. Big applause. MOVE IN on Faith smiling nervously.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE AND FAITH'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The children hugging each other.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sensational!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Fabulous!

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Four stars!

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (glued to the TV) Doesn't my scarf look great?

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Still applauding shyly, still smiling nervously. The SOUND of loud APPLAUSE. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, George and Faith riding beside each other. MOVE IN on Faith, the lights of San Francisco reflected in her eyes. Tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George moving down the hallway, edges into Jill's bedroom

dialogues.speaker: ON JILL 28
dialogues.text: Sleeping soundly. George reaches down, lifts the covers, picks Jill up. “She murmurs contentedly in her sleep, her arms tighten around her father's neck.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE AND JILL 29
dialogues.text: George carrying Jill down the hall into Marianne and Moll room. He lifts Marianne's covers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (whispering, to Martanne) Move over, honey, George. shovels Jill in toe-to-head next to Marianne, dra the covers over them, they shift and stir for a@ moment, but then fall back asleep. George kisses each girl.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tiptoeing down the hall, enters Jill's empty room, starts to undress. Sherry appears at the door, half- asleep, :

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Why aren't you sleeping in your own bed? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mommy hurt her back in the crowd. And I'm all pumped up. I can't sleep -- I don't want to keep Mommy up -- Sherry ignores the lie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You've been fighting again. Sherry turns back towards her room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Aren't you even going to congratulate me?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (as she goes) Congratulations. Sherry closes her door without looking back. GEORGE AND FAITH’S BEDROOM 31 Faith alone and still dressed, stands at the window, staring outside, watching the moonlight as it dances off the trampoline and the bicycles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the trees, almost hidden from view, a school bus waits, honking its HORN, PAN down the driveway to the children. running after it. Faith keeps her eye on them from the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (calling out) Hurry! Hurry! puddenly Sherry turns around, starts running back towards aith,

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: My barette! My hair!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Forget your barette! Run! Sherry turns around again, heads back towards the bus now Faith has one hand on the doorknob, she happens to look down at her other hand, it is clutching a medicine bot- tle.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Wait! Marianne's worm medicine! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Faith runs down the driveway in her nightgown, Sherry runs back, they meet halfway, Faith handing her the worm medicine, at the same time Faith rips a pin from her own hair and gives it to Sherry for a barette.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Make sure she takes one after lunch! Sherry grabs the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: She doesn't eat lunch! She's on a diet! Sherry is gone.

dialogues.speaker: FAITE
dialogues.text: Give it to her tea-cherr! But no one hears Faith, her voice drowned out by the bus' noisy departure. Faith shivers, starts to hurry back to- wards the house. On seeing the front door, she slows to a walk. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is fishing around underneath a kitchen cabinet. Faith appears.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's the matter? I can't find my glasses. Christ.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where did you leave them?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I left them right here --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Are you sure they're not on your desk?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm losing everything. I can't find anything anymore. George still fishing, comes up with a stub of a pencil, all pointless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: yp 33

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (holding it up) 21. 33 I can't even find a goddam pencil, What do the kids do, use them for pick-up stix?! And when I do finally rescue one, it's chewed over like a piece of licorice and it's got a point like a gum-drop! What do they do with my pencil points -- stick them in their goddam jujubes?!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Please, George, stop --

dialogues.speaker: GOERGE
dialogues.text: Stop what?! Where are my goddam glasses? I can't find my goddam glasses! How am I expected to work without my glasses?!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Then don't work --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (slowly and deliberately) I'm late on a Sunday piece. I've got the cover -- they close tomorrow -- don't work -- don't earn money -- that way we can all starve --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No one's starving, George --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (slapping an empty carton) Orange juice -- not even a goddam glass of orange juice. I've got the energy of a two-dollar whore in the morning. You know why? The goddam kids drink all the goddam orange juice!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We ran out -- I meant to get some on the way back last night --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: At two in the morning? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rf

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Two in the morning's been fine for you lately.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm talking about night before last, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was working. I was in town.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You were with your lady friend.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Ladyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: "Ladyfriend?' What kind of word is that?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's like 'fucking.' Only you don't tell anyone about it. A long, long silence. Faith slowly begins to scrub the breakfast dishes. Words form in George's mouth but no sound comes out. He stares at Faith's back, only the clatter of china resounding through the kitchen. Finally, George speaks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You want to talk about it? Faith scratches the leavings of some egg on a dish. George strides to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you think we should talk about it? Faith ignores George, keeps scratching at the egg with he nail.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I said -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George grabs the dish out of her hand and smashes it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DON'T YOU THINK WE SHOULD TALK ABOUT
dialogues.text: ITt! Faith grabs her own dish and smashes that to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NO, I DON'T WANT TO TALK ABOUT ITI
dialogues.text: George grabs another dish and destroys it.

dialogues.speaker: I THINK WE SHOULD TALK ABOUT IT
dialogues.text: Faith throws two dishes, they clatter. FAITH ;

dialogues.speaker: AND I DON'T WANT TO TALK ABOUT IT
dialogues.text: Now George picks up a whole armful of dishes and sends them splintering into pieces to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: I WANT TO TALK ABOUT ITII
dialogues.text: George is suddenly spent, he is left staring at Faith. But she drills him back, she does not give way at all. Their voices drop to some icy pitch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm packing my bag.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's already packed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's on the chair upstairs. I packed it last night. A moment between them, then George sprints upstairs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 24. ’ CONTINUED: (4) 33 Faith looks down at the dish she has smashed to the floor bends to pick up the pieces. The SOUND of George THUMPING above as Faith rests the pieces of dish on the sink, absent-mindedly tries to fit them together. George appears in the kitchen doorway, his suitcase besid him. He stares at Faith, daring her tv look up. But Faith re- fuses, her eyes remain on the pieces of dish, her fingers still silently fitting them together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks out of the kitchen and into the hallway. Whe he leaves, Faith turns away from the sink, to the kitchen window beside her. Tears.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY 34
dialogues.text: George puts his coat on by the front door, his suitcase b his side.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Locked, suspended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly's shoe nestled on a stair.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stares right through the shoe. His eyes move across to hi study.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: The corkboard, the desk, the pieces of George's life.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: A pair of child's jeans rumpled beneath a chair.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: A hint of Faith; the CLATTER of dishes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: He looks down at his hand frozen on the door knob. The hardest exit of his life. He snatches at the handle and slams the door shut. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FRYING PAN 35
dialogues.text: 7:30 AM. Sherry cooks chipped beef, stripping off meat, pouring in milk and cream, setting up plates, dropping in toast, a dexterous mother.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Jill, Marianne, Molly -- Bre-aak-fast! Perpetual motion now, Sherry adjusting place mats, fillin glasses of milk, flipping burnt toast into a rectangle of water in the sink, tucking the phone into her shoulder, spilling the beef onto plates, punching out a number on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Are you the service or are you Dr. Moore? -- You're Dr. Moore's nurse -- I want to make an appointment for Jill Dunlap -- she hurt her foot in ballet class last week, she's limping and she's getting worse... no, not out of school ‘til 3:30... no, piano lessons at 4:15... no -- sister... 4:45. Bye! Sherry runs down the hall from the kitchen with the pan o chipped beef.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (calling upstairs) I'm throwing it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith asleep. The CAMERA PICKS UP the upstairs hallway and Finds the 37 children's bathroom, twin sinks, soiled clothes mantling the toilet, toothpaste smeared, Jill and Marianne pee- ing, dressing.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling up again) I said I'm throwing it out --

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (yelling down) Go on and throw your shit out!  38 39 40 26.

dialogues.speaker: ON MOLLY 38
dialogues.text: Stumping into Faith's bedroom. She falls gently on to her mother. Faith grunts, rolls over. Marianne appears.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You getting out of bed, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You're never tired. Why are you so tired? You slept in yesterday. Molly tugs at Marianne's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (to Molly) Your sock's in the bathroom -- Faith, eyes closed, rolls over onto her stomach, points downwards.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (taking the clue) Your shoe's under the bed. Molly crawls under the bed. She finds her shoe, puts it o

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Jill runs in and pours herself a glass of Tang. Sherry looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Goddammit, I make the goddam breakfast and nobody eats it! Sherry pitches the whole pan of chipped beef into a sinkf of dishwater. The stuff lands with a splash.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (at the window) He's here. He's at the end of the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (from under the covers) One minute to eight. Sherry enters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: He's been waiting since quarter to.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Remember Monday, he came all the way up the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's car exhaust fuming, a yellow school bus appears

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Here comes the bus. Faith rises up now.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hurry up. The children all dive on Faith, they kiss her fiercely, she seems energized for the instant. But in a moment, when the children are gone, she falls ba onto the pillow, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S CAR
dialogues.text: Marianne, Jill and Molly climbing in.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Trotting down the steps of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Waiting in his car for Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Shifting impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Smiling as Sherry approaches. George swings open the door on the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Princess...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Faith by the curtains, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sherry ignores George, walks past and climbs on the bus. The Driver slams the door shut and the bus rolls away. 434 ON GEORGE 43a Throwing his car into gear.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Faith watches the tableau disappear.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BUS 45
dialogues.text: GO OUT on Sherry profiled against the bus window, her head bouncing gently against the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George chauffeuring, Jill, Marianne and Molly squeezed in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Are we going to stop for hot chocolate this morning?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure, honey.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What about basketball gum? Are we going to stop for basketball gum?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Let's skip the basketball gum this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Aw, Daddy, you said yesterday. we'd go to the crud shop today. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: It's true, Daddy. That's what you said.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What about you, Marianne? Are you desperate to go to the crud shop?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (looking out the window) Whatever you say, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: JTLL
dialogues.text: Where we going this weekend, Daddy? Are we going to see the basketball game, watch Jim play?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jim's not playing this weekend. He hurt his ankle -- I thought we might go up north... Jack London's house ++» the olden days --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Neat.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: We'll go alone with you, no one else?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Is that lady going to come?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sandy? I don't know. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Just wondered.

dialogues.speaker: STREET 47
dialogues.text: George pulls up, hustles the kids out of the car and into a co fee shop, a high school hangout, but nicer.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: How're the Dunlaps today?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good, thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: (beaming on the girls) How's Sherry?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Terrific. Takes the bus, likes to go with her friends. George hurries towards the back where the girls have sat down.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I want a Coke,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Aw, gee -- Shut up, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERMAN
dialogues.text: Four hot chocolates, right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You got it. The Counterman draws the hot chocolates.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What about the basketball gum?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Molly, you're getting a hot chocolate, how much crap can you eat before school?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: A lot.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Funn-ee. Molly, in a rush to drink her hot chocolate, spills it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jee-zus! Marianne, trying to help Molly mop up the mese, now spills hers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Holy Christ! Can't you watch out?!

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh God, we're going to be late for school.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: All right, all right, I'll give you a note, for crying out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George scribbling notes on a pad that hangs from the rear view mirror -- hands the notes to the children and pushes them out of the car. "Bye, Dad," "Have a nice day, Dad," "Get your car washed, Dad, it's all filthy." The children run for the empty school doorway. George watches them disappear inside. MOVE IN on George. A film of sweat on his face, his body collapsing with fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jeezus. His head tilts back wearily on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How does she do it? George takes one last glimpse at the school, blurry shapes of activity inside the windows. He breathes a huge sigh of relief and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The surf rolling in, a perfect sunlit day. PAN ACROSS a white beach to a simple redwood house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits behind a desk, staring at a Chinese lacquer cupful of razor-sharp pencils. Beside the pencil holder, an electric sharpener. George inserts a pencil in the sharpener, a light immediately flashes indicating the pencil is sharp. George withdraws the pencil, blows off a wispy curl of graphite. He now replaces the pencil in the cup, selects a new one, repeats the process.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 51 re oe 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith is in bed with Molly, Marianne and Jill, the chil- dren's schoolbooks discarded in front of them. Faith plays a board game ("SORRY!") with Molly, a TV flickers in the corner, the TV has Marianne and Jill's attention. They are:in the game too, but Molly is the only serious player.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mom! Go back twelve spaces.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: But that puts me back where I started from.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay, don't go back twelve spaces, (shrugs) How "bout six?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (turning from the TV. Hey, that's not fair...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Shut up. Molly hits Marianne on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Your turn. The SOUND of a CAR pulling up outside. No one Pays much attention. As a commercial comes on the TV, Marianne takes the opportunity to go to the bathroom, glancing out the window as she goes. The TV show comes back on. Faith and Molly continue with their game as Jill remains glued to the set. Marianne, however, remains at the window; she giggles.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What is it, Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: It's Daddy, with a policeman. Faith hesitates, squeezing the dice tight in her fists. Jill looks up, goes to the window. Now Jill giggles, too.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What Marianne said -- Daddy with a policeman. Molly leaves her mother and the game, joins the others at the bathroom window.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (giggling) It's Daddy all right, with the cop from in front of the school.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Well, someone better let them in. Jill runs downstairs as Faith throws on a baggy T-shirt and jeans. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George waiting patiently with a POLICEMAN. Jill stares through the door at the Policeman, the Policeman stares down at his shoes. Faith rushes to open the door, Molly and Marianne right behind her. Faith now opens the door, sees George. A second's silence.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hello, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I came to get my books.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I said I'd be here Wednesday at eight. (checks his watch) I'ma little late. This is Officer Knudson. He couldn't get away until now. KNUDSON tips his hat. Faith ushers them inside.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON, (POLICEMAN)
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ms. Dunlap. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: , 7s FAITH (warmly) That's quite Oh right. How are ‘ you, Officer Knudson? Knudson smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: Fine thanks, Ms. Dunlap. Knudson quickly glances down at his shoes again. Molly, Marianne and Jill follow his glance. They giggle; he touches his holster.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ’ Leo suggested I bring an officer along.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Who's Leo?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Spinelli, my lawyer. Faith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: (rocking on his heels) Well...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to George) \ Well, I guess everything's ready for you in the study. 52A Faith leads the way, followed by George and Knudson, children trailing.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to the children) You kids go upstairs now -- do your homework -- o~ “MOLLY Aw come on, Mom -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go ahead now. Do as your Mother says. Knudson looks at the children sternly, and they move Indian-file upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boxes of books around, the corrugated flaps tucked under each other. Faith reaches down to pick up a box.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay, I'll do it myself, George takes the box from her and carries it out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith has moved to the study window, through it she can see George flip open the trunk of his car, slide in the box.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: She turns around to find Knudson shifting uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We'll be all right, I promise --

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: Of course, Ms. Dunlap.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why don't you just go along?

dialogues.speaker: . KNUDSON
dialogues.text: I don't mind. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Well, how about a cup of coffee then?

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: Don't mind if I do. George appears. Knudson swallows.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: And you, George -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (heaving another box) No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Some tea?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you, no. George continues out again with the box.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to the Policeman) Let's go get you your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH AND KNUDSON 54
dialogues.text: Knudson guides around a pile of books, follows Faith into the kitchen. She pours some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Help yourself to cream and sugar

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. (tapping his pocket Do you mind if I smoke?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, please do. May I join you?

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: You betcha. Faith smiles again as Knudson offers her a cigarette, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you at the school, have I?

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, been there every day.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I guess I haven't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (trailing off) Been there... Faith smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You been out this way before?

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, this is a first for me.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too, George re-enters the house, glances towards the kitchen as he passes, continues into the library. Faith puffs cheerfully on her cigarette as George walks by.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (brightly, to Knudson) I guess I better get on with this. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knudson stays with his coffee as Faith moves back into the library with George. She reaches for a bookshelf , removes a few last books, hands them to George. But leaves one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Isn't that my Cassell's? George reaches for the book.

dialogues.speaker: , GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mine had the first twenty pages missing -- through 'avoirdupois.' He opens the inside front cover, "Faith DeVoe, Paris, 1967." George tosses the book back on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wonder what happened to mine.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You left it in the restaurant in Provence, remember? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What restaurant? y

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The one with that terrible piano player.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah -- the one who played the Beatles songs in French. George sings, he sounds like a bad Maurice Chevalier.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND GEORGE
dialogues.text: (together) ‘ET DE M'AIDER A COMPRENDRE...' ~ Knudson, embarrassed, coughs.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I think I'll wait in the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Knudson exits. A sheepish smile from Faith.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You always had such a pretty smile. Another smile from Faith.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about Knudson -- Spinelli insisted it was a good idea. You know... my Lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh, that's okay... the policeman seems very nice...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) We have to be grown up, I guess... y (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH \
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I guess... grown up... yu. yeah, sure, we should be grown up by now, George. Faith smiles again nervously. The telephone RINGS. Faith quickly pushes a last pile of books on the kitchen table towards George. She grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hello? -- oh hi? How're you? ~- No, no indigestion. Are you kidding? How could you afford indigestion after Mouton-Rothschild? -- I slept like a baby -- No, alone. She laughs. George has turned around by now, and is staring at her. Faith looks just past his glance, fond- ling the telephone cord. FAITH . Oh, I can't -- I have somebody here right now --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: "Somebody?’

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to George) Sssh. (to the phone) No, Jerry, you go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I can't, Jer -~ it's a stay-at- home kind of night -- washing the hair and everything, you know... Geroge is trying to stack books, but he can't get them the way he wants, he is too distracted by the conversatio

dialogues.speaker: PAITH
dialogues.text: Next week, maybe -- sure -- I'll be here -- 'bye, Jerry. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jerry? Jerry fucking Mills? ‘ (CONTINUED)  55

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. 40.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No fucking. We only had dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You ate dinner?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You ate dinner with an insurance man?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why not? It was lovely. He's charming. A really nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You drank wine with him?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure I drank wine. Good wine. I can't tell you how many premiums it must have cost him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You hate wine.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm developing a taste for it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You always drank milk. Don't you remember that Chinese headwaiter you said milk and meat would give you cancer?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's why I'm drinking wine now. Faith leads the way to the front door, George following. She waits by the door, but George doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who would have believed it? A goddamn insurance man.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We have to be grown up about this, George -- (pause) Do you want to say goodbye to the children? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ‘The children’? What's that -- "the children'? It sounds so legal.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (calling up) Jill! Marianne! Moll-lee!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DOORWAY 56
dialogues.text: George hangs there, and suddenly Molly, Marianne and Jill appear. Faith lines the children up for George to bend and kiss them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, kids. They hug George fiercely. "Goodnight, Daddy! Goodnight!" He holds on tight to them.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (looking around) Where's the policeman? Did Mom do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No no, darling, he just came to help me get my books. (a moment) Where's Sherry? — The girls look at Faith.

dialogues.speaker: FALTH
dialogues.text: (hesitant) She's staying overnight at Joanne's. An awkward silence, a door SLAMS upstairs. George looks upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh. George releases Jill, Molly and Marianne, stares longingl at them for a moment, then turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'll walk you to the car.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't bother.  ym 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Knudson gets out of his car as George crosses to his. Knudson calls up to Faith on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: (tipping his cap) G'night, Ms. Dunlap! Thanks for the coffee!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: You out here alone with the children now? After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: KNUDSON
dialogues.text: I'd get some bolts on those doors if I were you. Front and back. Knudson climbs into his car. Faith waves goodbye to Knudson and he waves back, George has already pulled out, Knudson following right behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George -- Jill, Marianne and Molly behind him -- slogging through the sand. The sun is hot, the girls uncomfortable George wipes his forehead, replaces his sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Real pretty, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I thought you didn't like the beach.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Is this the back way? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y) y 58

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, the front way. The front way is the scenic way. I thought we'd go in this way. The back's just a regular driveway.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANWE
dialogues.text: Next time, let's go the back way.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Yeah, the back way's okay for us.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Is he going to be there?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Doesn't she have a little boy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean Timmy.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (trying the name out, not liking it) ‘Timmy...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Timmy's with his father, Isn't it pretty?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You getting sand in your shoes, Dad? Don't you hate the sand in your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought you'd like this -- the beach and all -- the boats and everything --

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: No, the regular driveway's good enough for us, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought it was pretty this way -- Isn't it pretty? (desperate) Jee-zus, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sure, sure it's pretty, Daddy. Scenic.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, very scenic. They look up at several flights of steps to a deck. Jill takes a swipe at Molly, prompting her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's pretty all right. Molly now cues Marianne with a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Very pretty, Daddy. The beach and the boats and everything. Very pretty. (after a moment) Is it always this hot? They start climbing up the back stairs. George takes their little plastic suitcases from them, clutching them all in one hand, he gives Molly a boost with the others; Jill and Marianne trudge up the stairs in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRONT DOOR 58A
dialogues.text: A weathered teak door, old but expensive brass fittings. The exterior of the place understated, in good taste, an attention to detail,

dialogues.speaker: ON MOLLY
dialogues.text: waiting at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON JILL
dialogues.text: watching the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARIANNE
dialogues.text: staring at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: He bangs the knocker, nervously sneaking a look at the girls. After a long silence: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Is she pretty? Before George can answer, the door opens and SANDY appear a neat, attractive young woman, an open smile, and a wul- nerable air to her; bright, not wise but quick and charn- ing; freshness incarnate.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Semi-curious, semi-dazzled.

dialogues.speaker: ON SANDY
dialogues.text: beaming down at the waiting faces.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (to Molly) ro 5411) Hi. Moll Jill (to Marianne) Marianne. Sandy offers herself unblushingly.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Well, do I pass? Jill smiles warily, Molly looks past her into the house. Marianne hangs hack, holding on to her father by the suitcase,

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Come on in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children move right inside. As George passes Sandy, ghe kisses him on the lips. The children notice; make a ace.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (to George) I was looking for you at the back door. .

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Daddy likes the front way. He likes the boats. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (to the girls) I have lemonade and chocolate chip cookies...

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, great... (whispering to Molly) I hate chocolate chip cookies. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith lies in the tub, her eyes closed, enjoying these first few moments she has had to herself in a long time. She opens her eyes, reaches for some bath salts in a cabinet, sprinkles them in the bath. Also in the cabinet, a Chinese box, Faith lifts the lid; a half-smoked stick of marijuana, a box of matches. She lights the joint, inhales it deeply, enjoys it. Some trace of song forms on her lips, she begins to hum. It is the same song she and George began together last night. She sings softly, plaintively, sldwly:

dialogues.speaker: "SI JE COMMENCE A T'AIMEIZ
dialogues.text: PROMESS-TU D‘ETRE FIOELE ET DE M'AIDER A COMPRENORE... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: "CAUSE I COULDN'T STAND THE PAIN...'
dialogues.text: On the word “pain," she drifts. A moment. A distant memory comes back to her. The telephone RINGS. Faith reaches for a towel, climbs out of the tub and answers the phone.  y 61 62

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PHONE 61
dialogues.text: A photograph on the telephone table, George and Faith's wedding, Faith dancing with a silver-haired man, handsome almost dashing, a carnation in his buttonhole, a smart cutaway, striped pants. FALTH ; Hello? Oh hi, Mother, how's Dad? . I see... You're sure?... Hey, I read this thing about some holistic health place, they're really getting somewhere -- (stops) No, of course -- do it your way... No, I wouldn't dream of telling you what to do... fine, fine... No, they're away with George for the weekend... (pause) Yes, I know who she is. (another pause) I don't have money for a big city lawyer... but the one I have is supposed to be very good -- his name is Katz... Howard Katz -- he's known as the Butcher... (smiling) They make the best divorce lawyers, Mother -- (irritated) George is my business, Mother -- I'm sorry... I know how you feel -- (pause) Give my love to Dad, kiss him for me... and love to you, Mom. Yes, goodbye. Yeah -- I'm sorry, too. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVEWAY 62
dialogues.text: A four-wheel-drive pickup. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Faith reaches for her T-shirt and bent over, tries to figure out who the visitors are. The doorbell RINGS, Faith pulls on her jeans, runs downstairs.  63 48.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT DOOR 63
dialogues.text: Faith opens the door to an attractive man about 37, he wears jeans and a denim work shirt, his face direct yet reticent; the man's name is FRANK. Waiting in the truck, a@ younger man, RICK. Hitched to the truck is a backhoe,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Frank Henderson, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The tennis court. We spoke on the phone. Faith makes a face,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh my God --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You said the first of this month, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I did, but that was so long ago.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You don't want the tennis court anymore?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, well yes... well, I don't know... She looks past Frank to a grove of trees beyond the house

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I've wanted that tennis court for five years.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's a long time to wait. Frank turns around, glances back at his young partner in the truck; Rick waves.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's five hundred dollars to start. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Silence, A pause, 49. 63

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (echoing emptily) Five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's what we discussed, Mrs. Dunlap -- I set aside this time for you -- I turned down work, I hope you understand.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Of course I understand -- I do want you to go ahead with the court -- there's only one problem.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's that, Mrs. Dunlap?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't have five hundred dollars,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (looking up at the house) That's hard for me to believe, Mrs. Dunlap --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: My husband left me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: And right now I'm knee-deep in lawyers and separation agreements and child support and a whole bunch of shit -- it's hard right now -- so I don't know when I could pay you -- I only know I would pay you -- but I guess that's not good enough for you --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sorry -- I got a partner back there and stuff... you know how it is -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, well never mind. It would have been nice -- listen, thanks for coming out -- I hope I haven't cost you too much time --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, that's okay --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too -- Where were you going to-put the court? Faith tilts her head.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: In the grove. Frank looks over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, nice spot.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sorry --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry -- He walks away; then turns around.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: When would I get my five hundred?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The end of the month. I'll give you a note for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Okay, what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 io a a a)
t
7 i

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'11 do it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You will? That's great! I'll see you in the grove in two minutes. She disappears into the house as Frank heads out to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TRUCK 64
dialogues.text: Rick leaning out the window.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Get the backhoe off.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You got a check?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: For Chrissake --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Get it off!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. In a moment, they have laid some planks and Frank has rolled the backhoe down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith crossing to the grove in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Her husband left her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: . I see.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Besides, I like her. Rick watches Faith walking excitedly towards the grove, her shorts creasing in the sunlight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Her or her ass? Frank looks back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I hadn't noticed her ass.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Then there's something deeply wrong with you, Frank. See you later. Rick starts up the truck and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ruins of a magnificent house, all stone and arches, dried-up reflecting pools, charred timbers, the baths of Caracalla buried in the Northern California countryside. PULL BACK to reveal George and Sandy with Molly and Jill. They are standing on an overlook surveying the ruins; Marianne reads a brochure.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Spooky.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They say it was really beautiful once.

dialogues.speaker: SILL
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The night before Jack London was to move into this house, somebody set fire to it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Who set fire to it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They don't know. Could have been one of the workmen. Could have been somebody jealous -~ he was a very great author -- they don't know.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Then what happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jack London lost everything. All up in smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: But he still had his wife. Marianne consults her brochure.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: His second wife.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: She loved him a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He was everything to her. Sandy takes George's hand.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TRAIL 66
dialogues.text: A path leading from the ruins of the house to Jack London grave. Wildflowers and winter shrubs, the children gathering as they go.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What happened to Jack London's first wife? After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know, Jill, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What about his kids? Did he have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Sandy) There were children, weren't there?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: The leaflet says two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What else does the leaflet say? What does it say about the children, Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: . MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing. It doesn't say anything about the children. I guess he forgot about them after he married his second wife. curt To:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Such an important man -- That's all that's left?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Just a rock.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: It's a pretty rock. Jill climbs over the fence now and lays a flower by the rock. Molly and Marianne do the same; however, they do not use all their flowers, They braid some in each other's hair as George and Molly look at the rock.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How old was he when he died?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Forty.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Not old.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, not old. But he never stopped working -- he never stopped writing -- Jack London was a wonderful man -- PAN BACK with Jill towards George, he is all within himself.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You bet he was, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He was a wonderful man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jill takes George's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was a wonderful man. Marianne takes George's other hand. The two children comfort George. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ON SANDY
dialogues.text: She seems uncomfortable, almost disapproving at the close ness of George and the two children.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Let's go. The trail closes at four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill and Molly are in bed, Marianne sits on the edge of the other bed, lighting a candle. George is tucking the children in. Sandy enters in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: . Romeo and Juliet --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: This is the longest goodnight in history.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: He was just tucking us in -- Sandy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (gently) I'll help, Take your shower, George. She kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (exiting, to children) When I come back, I'1l kiss you goodnight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Why don't you kiss them now? George complies and kisses the children.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sandy, you are bossy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Yes I am, I want a little time with Daddy to myself.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You have a lot more time than our mother does.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, and she doesn't make us go to bed so early, either.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Your mother and I do things differently.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully, to the children) See you in the morning. George goes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTANNE
dialogues.text: I'll bet you want to make love to Daddy? Molly giggles.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (unblanching) Yes, I do. What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What's it like to make love to Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: A rare and beautiful thing. (to Marianne) Get into bed now, Marianne. Marianne gets into bed. Molly sits up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 om
t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: But what's it really like?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (after a moment, smiles) What's it really like? It's like eating ice cream. Sandy turns out the light, closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Goodnight, everybody. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "It's like eating ice cream...’ Molly starts to giggle hard. Marianne catches the giggles A torrent of giggles.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I think it's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George drives up, the SOUND of the children singing a round, "Row, Row, Row Your Boat," George and Sandy singing along with them. Sandy gets out now, waves good- bye to the children.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: McDONALD'S - LATE AFTERNOON (RAIN) 70 George's car rolls in, As George pulls into a parking slo the windows steam the instant he turns the wipers off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: All right, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I want a Big Mac, a strawberry shake, a double french fries, and an apple pie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: |o™ GEORGE | 0.K. What do you want, Ji11?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: ! I want a double cheeseburger, a vanilla shake and two apple pies.

dialogues.speaker: ' GEORGE
dialogues.text: You can't have two apple pies.

dialogues.speaker: \ JILL
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm having one instead of my french fries.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ' . You can't have two apple pies.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Then Molly can't have french fries and apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I can so -- that's what I had . last time -- . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i If you can have french fries and apple pie -- I can have two apple 1 pies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair --

dialogues.speaker: ' MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: ) Shut up yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Shut up, both of you! (silence) It's almost six o'clock. I'm supposed to have you home by six o'clock. Silence. Just the sound of rain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you want, Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 oo ym 71 72

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, nothing -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing, I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You've got to have something, you haven't eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll have a Big Mac, a chocolate shake, a double french fries and a cherry pie.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: She can't have that, if I can't --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Never mind! George gets out of the car, hustles through the rain. Marianne leans forward, turns on the car radio. Jill snaps her fingers to the music. Molly plays with the directional signals. Marianne observes her father through the restaurant window. INT. McDONALD'S 71 Inside -- "YOU, YOU'RE THE ONE... AT McDONALD'S! AT McDONALD'S!"

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERGIRL
dialogues.text: Yes sir, can I help you? George's face is blank, he is struck dumb for the moment. Now he gropes, but no words come out.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERGIRL
dialogues.text: (still smiling) Yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I'd like -- Jeezus, I forget what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is handing out the food. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here's for you, Molly -- a Big Mac, a big french fries, a strawberry shake and an apple pie -- Jill, a double cheeseburger, a vanilla shake and two apple pies, Marianne -- a Big Mac, a chocolate shake, a big french fries and a cherry pie.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: What did you get, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A fishwich. The girls tear into their packages, start eating. George does not open his sandwich. He rests his head against the rainy window, peers out.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPING MALL
dialogues.text: Stereo stores, hardware, furniture and florists flanking huge K-Mart, the shopping center dismal and deserted in t late Sunday rain.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to eat your fishwich, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, he’s thinking. Silence, the children squint at George, his head in profi leaning against the window. “MOLLY You angry, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Shut up... he's just sad, GO OUT on a cacophony of children's straws, noisily suck- ing on the bottoms of their empty plastic containers. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith comes running down the steps as George drives up with the children, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hi! .Hil Did you have a good time?!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Yeah! We went to McDonald's. The children rush past her into the kitchen, George ap- pears with the plastic suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'll take them. Faith reaches for the suitcases, starts to move back in the house with them, but George follows her. Faith turns to George in the doorway; they are neither inside nor outside the house, but perched on the doorstep protected from the rain by an overhang.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {suddenly} It's Sherry's birthday next week.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (turning) Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe she'd spend the day with me -- I have tickets for the Ice Capades.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Well, you'll have to discuss that with her,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I already did -- I called her at school -- she said she didn't want to go. .

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Well, I guess she doesn't want to go, then --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought perhaps you might speak to her --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't think so, George. I think it's between you and her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have a present for her. A portable typewriter. An Olivetti. George shifts his body to steal a glance at Sherry inside

dialogues.speaker: FAITE
dialogues.text: That's nice, George. Sherry really wants a typewriter. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll come by with it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The other night, when I picked up my books, I might have taken a few of your cookbooks by mistake.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (laughing) Don't worry about it, George. You know me, they were mostly decoration anyway. Besides, I'm changing the kitchen around.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm going to put a big Rya rug in front of the fireplace --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What about the couch -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Right behind the rug, facing the fireplace. (pauses) How did you know about the couch?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was the last thing we talked about... when we were talking. George breaks off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Faith stares at him for a moment, then turns to go back in the house. Frank appears, heads past Faith out to the driveway. George, surprised to see Frank, stares at him Frank hesitates in the doorway. :

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: George, this is Frank Henderson.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (courteously) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Frank, this is -- was my husband. Frank offers his hand. George shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hullo. Frank keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'1l be back.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Okay, Frank. George turns to watch Frank climb into his truck, which was invisible behind the garage. There is a shell over the truck now.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Just someone helping out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Helping out?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: He's building our tennis court. GEORGE . Tennis court?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure. Out in the grove.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't want any goddam tennis court at my house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Your house? Are you kidding? We kind of think it's our house.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ours?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Me and the children,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is my house. I fixed up this house.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You're not at this house anymore, George. You walked out -- remember? Feet first. Or maybe there was something else preceding you.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: at the kitchen window, peeking out at her mother and father through the rain. George sees her and Sherry turns away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (back to Faith) This house isn't your house yet.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
