dialogues.text: It's getting late, George -- the children have school tomorrow. Maybe we should talk about this some other time. Goodnight, George. She closes the door, George turns, sees Sherry peering at him through the window again. FOLLOW George, tiptoeing through the puddles under the overhang, past the kitchen window, Sherry watching her father thro the vapored glass. George stops, suddenly waggles his fingers at Sherry in greeting. She doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: backing off from the window, but keeping her eyes on George's car as it splashes off into the wet night. cur TO:  75 oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hr
p
4 we ‘ 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feverish activity, Frank working with a grader, Sherry an Faith helping along, heaving rocks, they are building a dry wall. Jill, Molly and Marianne play in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GRADER 76
dialogues.text: Sherry in Frank's lap, learning how to operate the machin working the legnth of the court. Sherry rolls over a boundary. Frank laughs, backs it up for her. Jill, Molly and Marianne begging for turns on the grader.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: Glancing over at Frank, when Frank catches her glance, sh turns back quickly to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND FRANK 77
dialogues.text: Frank trying to keep up with Faith as they work with ston Sherry alone now on the grader in the b.g. Jill, Moily and Marianne hitch rides with their big siste

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I want to leave this end open. I was thinking about.a little gazebo -- you know, like you see at Wimbledon,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We'll just rum the mesh up to this point -- then we'll have this, sort of tennis house -- a summer house ~-- like the Japanese -- where the children can have iced tea and chicken sandwiches and bring their friends -- they could play tennis all day here --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Lucky kids.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's going to be beautiful, Frank? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes... very unusual.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you if you thought it was going to be unusual. I asked you if you thought it was going to be beautiful. Pause, Frank looks at Faith.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, it will be beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's better. (smiles) Want something to drink? Beer -- Coke -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Beer soumds good. Faith goes.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: She sees Faith Looking in the refrigerator as she enters the kitchen. Molly sits by, playing with some points.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Beer.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Beer for Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Beer for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You drinking beer?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure I am -- you know I was thinking =“ we ought to ask Frank to stay for dinner -- I think we could get the wall done by dinner -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask him?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, you ask him. He likes you.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, go ahead, ask hin.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Ask him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Aw c'm'on, Sher -~- After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I'll ask him on one condition -- that I eat dinner with you -- and that none of the other kids come.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (pauses , smiles) Okay, it's a deal. Sherry exits.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (as Sherry goes) I wonder if he likes chicken. Doesn't everybody like chicken? Chicken is always good. (hesitates) Isn't it? (bustling immediately) Well, I think I°11 give him chicken. Do we have any chicken? (throws open the refrigerator) I thought I had those thighs. Where in God's name did our thighs o to? We ate them? Maybe the reezer -~ don't we have a chicken in the freezer -- or is it turkey -- Oh my God, it's that terrible old Easter turkey!

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘FAITH (CONT'D) Turkey!? That's terrible! Molly has been watching the performance.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, relax, will you, Mom? He's only a guy.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A linen tablecloth, the good silver, heirloom candlestick

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: How about some more, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No thanks, I've really had enough.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why, you've hardly eaten anything.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: (quickly) I've eaten a lot. He smiles. Faith smiles, She nervously gulps some wine. Sherry's eyes stay on her mother.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Frank) More stuffing? Stringbeans? Gravy? Faith hears herself, reacts to herself,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: ».. I know, too pushy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, not pushy at all. You're real nice. And you're a real good cook. SHERRY ’ Sorry to interrupt you, folks, I'd like another glass of wine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (gently) You've already had two.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Mother, I'd like another glass of wine. Frank laughs, Smoke drifts in from the stove.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh my God, the Indian pudding. Sherry turns to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Don't mind her, she's all nervous tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: coming in with a mess.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sorry, guys, the Indian pudding looks like a dead Cherokee.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) She's been making Indian pudding ever since I was born, and tonight she burns it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Could I give you something else? Fix you some cheese and fruit? No, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I could make you some custard -- that's quick -- or some cheese and fruit?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Mother, you just asked Frank that. pow, many glasses of wine have you ha (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'd love a cup of coffee. Faith moves to the stove and pours boiling water over grounds in a filter.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry, get out some of that nice brandy -- you'll have some brandy, won't you, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Uh --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Get the brandy, Sherry. Faith brings the coffee pot to the table, pours some into a delicate china cup for Frank. Sherry fishes in a cabinet full of bottles.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Which brandy is it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The one with the four stars. Sherry locates the brandy, sets the dusty bottle on the table. Faith rushes to wipe it off. Frank studies the bottle tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Gee, I don't know, Faith --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (nervously) The brandy makes the coffee taste better, and the coffee makes the brandy taste better. Or is it the other way around? Anyway, have some. Sherry looks back and forth from Faith to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: That's Daddy's brandy. Frank reaches for the brandy now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Faith) You'll join me?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Of course. Faith drains her glass of wine, pushes a snifter towards Frank who pours out the brandy.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (getting up) I think I'll do the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Leave them, honey, I'll take care of them in the morning. Time for you to go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Go to bed! It's only ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: . FAITH
dialogues.text: You've got school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe Sherry would like a little brandy.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Milk.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Could you get it yourself, honey?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: What's this ‘honey’ shit all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry, that's enough of that. Frank laughs as Sherry goes to the refrigerator, pours herself a glass of milk, gulps it down. Now Sherry returns to the table, picks up the brandy bottle, replace it in the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Good night, Frank. I'11 see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (brightly) Good night, Sherry! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Faith) ) And I'll see you, soon. Sherry leaves, Frank looks down warily at his snifter of | brandy. ‘ FAITH : - Would you like a cigar to go with ' . that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't smoke cigars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ' I haven't any -- uh -- I haven't used any in several -- wh -- months, what I mean is -- uh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the hallway) | C'mon, Mom, you know what he smokes! ' A door slams, Faith flinches, Frank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : ~~ I'll try a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: ) Faith jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: ' FAITH
dialogues.text: I won't be a moment, they're just i in the front room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: , Do you want me to come with you?

dialogues.speaker: ' _ FAITH
dialogues.text: No, stay here. You're comfortable here, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Makes no difference to me. Frank smiles. Faith smiles anxiously. Now she goes.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM 80
dialogues.text: ~~ Cozy, a fireplace. Faith turns around and she finds Fr right behind her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Faith goes to a bookshelf, uncovers a dust: one old dry cigar. Gives it to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH AND FRANK
dialogues.text: y box, pulls out Faith sipping her brandy, Frank lighting up his cigar,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got any music?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Music?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I see you got a stereo.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sure, we got some -- She gets up, moves to the stereo. coloring books and National Lampoon record albums. She pushes past some &, to a pile of worn

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: How about the March of the Children from The King and I?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't believe I know that one.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm only kidding, it's just a joke -- it's Molly's ifavorite, Faith puts a record on, probably an old Rolling Stones; a slow one. Faith and Frank sit listening to the music, other, Faith on a couch, Frank in a chair, t turntable bridging the gulf facing each he stereo of embarrassment between then. Frank taps a finger on his cigar in time to the music, Faith pats the side of the couch, then nervously but silently snaps a finger.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I love this song.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's great,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you want to dance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Dance?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't you dance?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Not in a long time. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You want to dance now?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh no, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm just nervous.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Scared. It's been a long time since I danced -- been alone with aman other than my husband. Frank nods understandingly. The only SOUND is the music. The song continues.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Could I kiss you? Faith looks at hin, immediately shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No no, I don't think so -- Faith drops her head, digs her nails into her fingertips. More silence. The record ends, only the sound of the need bumping against the label. . Silence. Silence. Silence. Out of the silence: ‘(CONTINUED)  75. .

dialogues.speaker: _ FAITH
dialogues.text: ~~ (almost inaudibly) I mean ‘yes.' Frank moves to her, sits beside her on the couch. Faith i | motionless, Slowly, he reaches for her blouse, and un- VW buttons it to the waist. The blouse hangs loosely. 5 Faith's head is still down. Frank lifts her chin with h , hand now. For the first time, Faith looks at Frank. The kiss. Passionately.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE DOOR FRAME 81
dialogues.text: The door is slightly open. Sherry's hand reaches in from ) the hallway, gently closes on the brass knob, pulls the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkness, a child's cough, then another cough, Geo ' comes into view. 6

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Timmy's coughing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll go --

dialogues.speaker: I GEORGE
dialogues.text: ' No, I'll do it. You stay where you are,

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE 83
dialogues.text: FOLLOW George as he opens the door of a dark room, a nigh light dim in a socket, TIMMY, a five-year-old, lying in ~ fm a trundle bed. George squats next to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Timmy?

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: I can't breathe. George checks around, adjusts a croup kettle. Unscrews the top, stirs the mixture. Reaches for a glass,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Want a little Coke?

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: It's too warn.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good for you stomach --

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Will you come with me to the bathroom if I throw up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure, Timmy. George puffs the pillow under Timmy's head, points the ke gets some Coke down him, tucks in the covers. Timmy rests

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Where's Mom?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Where's Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Timmy?

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Daddy --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He's in Los Angeles, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: You're sleeping over?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why yes, Timmy. Of course. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Don't you want to go home and be with your own children? 83 Timmy rolls over, turns away, quiet now. George looks dow at him. He checks the croup kettle again, now starts for Sandy's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up as George enters.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Thanks --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He's okay now.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: You coming back to bed? I wanted to go.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay. You always go -- George crawls into bed, Sandy spoons into him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Sean never did.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you miss him?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Never. (turns to George, very close, looking him in the eye) Even when I was with him, I was lonely. I never have that feeling with you. And I knew I wouldn't -- as soon aS we -- (waits) -- got going. I don't like being alone. I mean I can stand it of course -- but I want a friend. You're my friend, George. I like you. I love you. (good naturedly) And if you don't come through, I'11 find somebody else. (CONTINUED)
t 7
bi
1 oo 1 t

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George reaches for Sandy through the darkness. Now Sandy reaches for him. They find each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vacuum WHIRRING, Faith cleaning up, picking up glasse emptying ashtrays.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Jill, Marianne and Molly can be seen playing in the yard; bouncing on the trampoline; tossing a frisbee.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Following her mother around, yelling over the NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you I have an appendicitis --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry, you have a fever.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: It's my pancreas -- Faith keeps vacuuming away, Sherry pursuing her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Pancreatis --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry, go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: " SHERRY
dialogues.text: (right after her) Gallstones --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You do not have gallstones -- just go to bed -- drink the tea with honey -- and I'll make you a nice rice pudding.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: All right, don't have a nice, rice pudding! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: Vacuuming. suddenly turning around, finding Sherry starin at a pillow, examining the indentations, the aftermath of last night. Faith grabs the pillow from Sherry, fluffs it up, tosses it in the corner of the couch. Sherry says something.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (softly, almost inaudibly) I hate Daddy. Faith can't hear. She turns the vacuum off,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What's the matter? The vacuum winds down. In the silence, Sherry stands froz in the middle of the room, staring at the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I hate Daddy. Sherry walks out of the room. Faith follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weaver's loom, not used recently. Sherry sits down besi it, on one side of a window. Through the window, the other children can be seen.playing in the yard. Faith enters the room, moves to Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You okay...? Faith and Sherry are on both sides of the window now, fra it, the other children noiseless blurs beyond.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Why did Daddy leave us?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't think he left you. I think he left me.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I'm never getting married.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don't say that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y y a0.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: What's the point? After a moment: FAITH . - I think when two people love each other, it's like -- I don't know -- like going through doors -- you go through the doors together at first -- then one person gets ahead --

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: But if they love each other, don't they wait for each other?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I guess so,

dialogues.speaker: . SHERRY
dialogues.text: It's all Daddy's fault.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's no one's fault. No one's to blame. Just time. Another moment.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Do you wish for you and Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You and Frank?

dialogues.speaker: . FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh no... One of the things your Daddy said about growing up, is you stop wishing. Things either come to you or they don't. But if I were to wish for anyone right now, I'd wish for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Timmy running along the water's edge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As they approach the house, they start to sprint, George pours it on with everything he has. He wins, turns to fin Timmy has given up. George trots back to Timmy, lifts him up in the air, a big dog comes tearing out of the house, starts snapping at George's heels, George trips, falls down, now picks himself up, kicks sand at the dog, Timmy falls to his knees to comfort the dog. MOVE IN on George, bewildered. ;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith leads the way in, Sherry, Jill, Marianne and Molly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Who's due?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Henrietta's due.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Lemme get it! Lemme get it!

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Shut up, squirt. Henrietta doesn't lay for anyone but Mommy. Faith moves to a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (cooing) Hello, baby, hello, baby, you got something for me? The chicken looks Faith in the eye. Faith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You bet you do. With great care, Faith edges her hand under the chicken. She is ever so gentle, the chicken lifting up slightly to help her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It's so mean, it's her baby.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No baby, Moll, no baby. MO: . (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y y) 88

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's only Mommies in here, no Daddy around to make the egg into a baby. Faith comes up with the egg, a beautiful brown egg. She h it to a candler,

dialogues.speaker: MARTANNE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Make it into salad, darling, and put it in your sandwich for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'm not eating anybody's baby for lunch, :

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We could hard-boil it --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You hard-boil it. You have it for your lunch. Faith smiles. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith with the children in an old store, trying on junky things. Faith enjoying herself, the children running to keep up with her quick eye and instinctive taste. Jill finds an old leather bag with a strap. Marianne loca a white linen Victorian apron. Molly appears with a pair earrings.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What do you think of these earrings?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I love them, they're really great.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I think they're ugly.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (lowering her voice) Let me see those earrings. Faith examines them.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I think they're amethyst.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (whispering loudly) Yeah! Amethyst! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: They worth anything?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'd say about three hundred dollars. You kids got what you want? Okay, let's get out of here. Faith and the children hurry with their things to the cou by the door. The OWNER totals them up.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Four dollars for the bag -- two dollars for the peasant's apron ~- you want the earrings? -- that's three hundred and six dollars. Faith looks down at the kids, leaning elbow-to-elbow on t counter, looking up at her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Nice try, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow street, a row of shacks, this gloomy section in stark-contrast to where Faith and the children live. Faith and Marianne are picking up Molly.

dialogues.speaker: FAITE
dialogues.text: "Bye, Mrs. Jackson! Thanks for having her. (prompting Molly) Bye!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, 'bye! See you tomorrow, Roxanne! Molly waves to a black, pig-tailed friend. Faith grabs he hand, they dodge through puddles towards the car. Mariann follows close.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Did you have a good time, Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Did you give Mrs. Jackson the clothes?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Where we going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y om 89

dialogues.speaker: FALTH
dialogues.text: See a friend of mine. What'd Mrs. Jackson say when you gave her the clothes?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: She said thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Did you have anything to eat?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hamburgers --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's good...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: ~- with weird gravy. Blaaaah...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Ssh. They climb into the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (to Faith) What friend you going to see?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Howard Katz.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: My lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You mean Judy Katz's father?

dialogues.speaker: ' FAITH
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: He's on our side?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeececch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George driving up to the front of the house. He climbs ou of his car, carrying a portable typewriter. He starts for the door, stops on hearing LAUGHTER from the tennis court

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith and Frank taking a break, sitting near the almost- finished dry wall, sharing a cigarette, Frank seated in the grader, Faith next to him. George calls out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Faith... Faith... He hasn't called too loudly. And they haven't heard him. George reaches through the window of his car, gives a lig toot to his HORN.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH AND FRANK 90B
dialogues.text: Frank looking over, Faith finishes her cigarette, now wanders across the half-finished court,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George waiting, shifting the typewriter from one hand to the other. In the b.g., the grader starts up with Frank at the wheel,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where's Sherry?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: She went to the city with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The city?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The ballet. Mother took her to the ballet for her birthday. Silence. Frank eriss-crossing on the grader in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I see. Faith starts into the house, George follows her.  92 93 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith opening the refrigerator, pulling out a container o egg salad, slicing open a pocket bread. George observes her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Frank's lunch. He loves Syrian bread.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is he, an Arab?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, he's not an Arab. She quickly stuffs the bread, snatches two beers out of t icebox, assembles the sandwiches and beer on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I brought Sherry the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The typewriter I told you about. The one for her birthday. Faith notices the case for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... that's great. She reaches for it. He pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I want to give it to her. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay... well, I'll be back. George follows Faith out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen door slams behind them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Incidentally, next time Sherry goes out of town, I'd like to know,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: ‘Out of town'? She's just with Mother for her birthday. I'm sorry, George. George starts to follow Faith, then stops, glances over a the tennis court, observes Frank grading. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's the tennis court?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That clay's going to run like molasses. You should have used en-tout-cas.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: 'En-tout-cas'? If I could spell it, I'd use it,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tennis courts are tricky things, you can't just rush into them. If you're going to build one, you might as well build it right.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Frank and I are doing fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll bet you are. How much is he sticking you?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You mean what's the price? Frank is very reasonable,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Glad to hear it. Because I'm not paying a nickel for that piece of shit you call a tennis court -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 rn

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Who's asking you to? Oh, George, I have to go, okay? Frank's beer is getting warn, She goes, he watches her.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND FRANK , 94
dialogues.text: Faith giving Frank his lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (from the driveway) Hey, bud-deel Frank looks around.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It looks like shit! You couldn't play horseshoes on that volcano! Frank can't quite hear,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Ignore him, please don't Pay any attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: But what'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I said FUCK YoU! George jumps in his car, screeches out, burning rubber li a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night black, the lights of the house squares of light cutting through the darkness. PAN OFF the house to a car pulling up at the end of the driveway. The driver gets out quietly, reaches into the seat beside him, pulls out black case. The door to the car is closed quietly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tt is George. His footsteps crunch through the gravel to- wards the house.

dialogues.speaker: BOLT 96
dialogues.text: The bolt is snapped open by a hand. The door swings wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, standing with the typewriter at the front door, Faith facing him. Silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Hello, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hi. I brought Sherry her typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Now? Tonight? It's late, George. Look, it's really no use. She really doesn't want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But it's her birthday. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why don't you just leave it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. I want to give it to her myself.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: But if she doesn't want you to --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I want to give my kid her birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Your kid doesn't want her birthday present! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: y A moment. 90. 97 Sherry's door closes mid-sentence.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Five minutes, that's all?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: She's very angry, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm angry.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You roundheeling it on a tennis court with some overage redneck hippie.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I think you better go.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm going to give my child her birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Your ‘child' does not want her birthday present! Sherry's door SLAMS again upstairs. Now Faith tries to cl the front door where George is standing.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Please go, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE FAITH
dialogues.text: No. This is my house and I don't want to hear it -- this is my kid -- you're in stop, George -- will you violation of our separation please stop...? agreement -- my lawyer says --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Fuck your lawyer! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Faith slams the front door shut and bolts it. George kick at the door.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT
dialogues.text: George pitches the typewriter through a mullion, the glas smashes, George snakes his arm past a shard of glass, fli the bolt. Faith starts to run, but George grabs her, stee her out the door and slams it. Bolts the door. Faith screams, starts hitting on the door. The glass is jagged, she tries to reach through, scratches her arm. Tries again, the glass too sharp and narrow to get throug

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS 98
dialogues.text: The children pressed against the windows, the windows all fogged up. Sherry yells down at George.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Get out of here!
pounding now on the front door, but George props a chair against it. Faith starts to reach in once more past the : broken glass, George props another chair.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (through the broken window) How do you like it?! How do you like getting locked out of your own house?! Now George runs upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the door, screaming now. Suddenly Molly appears, frame by the chairs braced against the door.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Open the door! Open the door, Molly!! But Molly can't get anywhere, the pair of bentwood chairs are wedged tight against the knob. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY 100A
dialogues.text: It's stuck -- it's stuck! Faith takes off, running around the house, trying doors. All are locked.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY 101
dialogues.text: George runs up the stairs, sees Sherry panicked in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE HOUSE 102
dialogues.text: Faith running around frantically, pounding at windows, trying to get in.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: George! For God's sakes, George!

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY 103
dialogues.text: Sherry has locked her door. George crashes right through the door. As he bursts in, Sherry throws a radio at him, then a hanger, he dives for her, forces her over and whip her with the hanger. She fights back, screaming. She begi to claw at him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Fucker! Bastard! Sherry twists away from George and hurls a lamp at him. I crashes, the bulbs flying. Screams from the other childre converging now on the doorway. George dives for Sherry no and tackles her to the bed, and begins slapping her again this time with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (screaming) Bastard! Fucker!

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Shrieking, racing around the house, kicking at the walls, her screams drowned out by the mayhem upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has Sherry down on the bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Marianne runs and jumps on him, tries to pull him off, he flips her away and then Sherry, taking the moment, grabs a pair of scissors and holds them to George. George freez

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Fucker! Bastard! I hate you -- Sherry keeps the scissors on George -- no one moves. Sherry trembles, then suddenly throws the scissors to the floor, wanders into the hallway. George stands frozen. Now he takes a step towards Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (erying) Daddy, don't -- don’t, Daddy -- George takes hold of Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sherry --

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Honey, please --

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Bastard.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Talk to me. Silence. Now Jill comes to Sherry, strokes her hair. Marianne puts her arms around George. He kisses her fin- gers as they reach around him.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You cut yourself, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (pleading to Sherry) Honey, honey -- Sherry turns around, spent.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: What is it -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith is screaming for Molly. . 107A

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Open the kitchen door! Open it! Open it! Molly appears behind the door, strains for the bolt, can't reach it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Get a chair! Get a chair! Molly grabs a kitchen chair, drags it to the door, stands on the chair, opens the bolt. Faith charges inside, Molly running after her.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY 108
dialogues.text: George trying to touch Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Give me a chance --

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You're coming over tomorrow, aren't you, Daddy -- to pick us up for the weekend...? George swallows, blinks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sherry... Sherry is unflinching.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Okay. Faith appears, Sherry runs to her, Faith folds her into h arms, buries her nose into Sherry's hair. They hold tight Faith's eyes never leave George.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (to George) You want something to eat? I could make you a hamburger with the onions chopped in. George checks Faith for an instant. Faith stares back at him,

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Do you want a band-aid for your arm, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay. Now George edges to the top step. He freezes, turns toward Faith again. He is helpless, vulnerable, overcome all at once.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Faith...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Get out. George looks at Faith and the children, but they only sta back at him. George goes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE 110
dialogues.text: Coming down the stairs, he sees the smashed front door, notices as if for the first time, the bentwood chairs pus up against it. He very carefully removes the chairs, puts them back in their exact position in the hallway. He then replaces the cushions, squaring them off. George sees the typewriter. He picks it up, throws open the bolt on the door, looks back up the stairs; Faith and the children are watching him. George leaves. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks through the class out into the gravel of the driveway. George walks normally at first and then, in- voluntarily, begins to run. GO OUT on George sprinting towards his car.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY COURT
dialogues.text: JUDGE SCHULTZ, a tired woman in her fifties, presides, Sprinkled around the courtroom, Hispanics, Blacks, Public Defenders. On either side of the aisle, George and Faith, Howard beside Faith. Beside George, his lawyer, SPINELLI, a natty three-pieced type. In front of the Judge, a Mexican WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (Spanish) He violates the children! A MAN jumps to his feet, crumpling his old Panama hat in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (Spanish) She sleeps with the boss! A terrible babble of Spanish, silenced by Judge Schultz's gavel.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND GEORGE 112
dialogues.text: in front of the bench now with their respective lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I thought we had a separation agreement, visitation rights --

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: But this incident --

dialogues.speaker: SPINELLI
dialogues.text: What incident -~ no police report -- I would like to make a stipulation that we not be dragged into court every time it pleases Mrs. Dunlap or her attorney -- Stipulate one, Your Honor, that Mrs. Dunlap be restrained from -- Mixed in with the above montage of Spanish and English- speaking VOICES. "The children are remanded to the State Home... "The husband being derelict in his payment is required to..." The legalese winds down and for the first time, Schultz c be heard. Howard squeezes Faith's hand, retires to a seat behind her. Spinelli moves behind George, now George and Faith are left alone and side-by-side, standing in front of Judge Schultz. Faith takes a half-step away from Georg

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dunlap, your insistence on limiting Mrs. Dunlap's custody during vacations seems poorly timed. This Christmas the children will reside with their mother. (to Faith) As for you, Mrs. Dunlap, to deny the father the right to take the children to school three times a week seems an unnecessary hardship. If he so wishes, and he is the only father they have right now, why shouldn't he enjoy that privilege. Do you understand, Mrs. Dunlap?

dialogues.speaker: . FAITH
dialogues.text: I do, I mean I will.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dunlap?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I agree, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You'd better. I don't want to see either of you two in here again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith walking rapidly, Howard running to keep up with her

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: We bring in Sherry, we show the welts from the hanger, we expose the broad -~-

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What broad?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The one he’s shacked up with, let me work him over -- Faith stops.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Work him over? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Right. Put him in Soledad with the Beaners and the Schvugs. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Just no.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You want your house? You want your kids?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What do you think they're going to do? That dago lawyer of his is not known for his Christianity and the Iron Maiden on the bench is no bargain either. What do you say, Faithie?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You better -- here he comes now -- 113A George and Spinelli block them on the courthouse ste

dialogues.speaker: SPINELLI
dialogues.text: (interrupting, ahead of George) Mr. Dunlap wants to pick up the children tonight at seven instead of six -- he has a late appointment in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Under no circumstances --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (tired) It's all right, Howard, I won't be home anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (overhearing, now joining) What do you mean you won't be there?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: My father's sick. George blinks, pulls at his coat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (tense) What's the matter with him?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't know. He went in for some tests. And they're keeping him there --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So you're going up -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'll be back Monday. Mrs. McGovern is going to sit. You can pick them up whenever you want tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll bring the kids up to your parents. There is a moment. Spinelli and Katz look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Iwill. It's easy.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Please, George, don't. They're okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well give French my love -- tell him I'll be coming up. Spinelli and Katz exchange more looks.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I want to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 113A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 114 115 Silence. Spinelli takes George's arm and starts off in one direc- tion down the courthouse steps, Katz pulls Faith in the other. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walking down the corridor. Faith emerges from a bathroom off the corridor. They see each other, move down the hall together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRENCH, Faith's father, is in bed, a hulk of a man, fragi now, a breathing machine beside him, the tubes detached f the moment; green coils for breathing in, pink coils for breathing out, a balloon to register inhalation and exhal ation, the whole operation monitored by an oxygen tank which looms over the bed. An IV drips into French's arm. On the floor underneath the mattress, a drain bottle with a tube leading to a catheter. The room is a tangle of tubes, drips and drains coils; but discernible behind all the rubber and hardware a man.is there -- French. Faith and George freeze at the sight of French, shocked by his condition. Now Faith moves towards her father.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Poppa. -

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Where's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Outside.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: How're you doin', honey? (seeing George hanging back) You too, George. George hurries over, leans in from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Good to see you two together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks, French.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: You are together?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: "Sure'?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean we are.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: (to George, a faint smile) You wouldn't shit me, would you, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) No, Poppa. Silence, as French takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: I miss that house -- how's that house?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE FAITH
dialogues.text: It needs some work. Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: 'Terrific.' 'It needs some work.' You two better get together.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: George is right, Poppa, when you get out, you'll bring your tools a one Sunday... like you always Ce

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Cut it out, will you? (drilling Faith and George) You're a couple of lousy liars. George and Faith stand there with French. There is an exchange through the silence among the three of them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (speaking up) You're right, Poppa. We've broken up. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Forgive me,

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) Not a chance. Silence again.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: George -- He motions him to move close. Faith releases French's hand, steps away.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know. French smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: (to George) Did I ever tell you about the time you went on your honeymoon, I entered your father in the Bass Derby -- he cheated, hooked that smallmouth with live bait. Sonofabitch -- your father couldn't even tie a fly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My father was an asshole and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: But he was the only asshole you ever had.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, French, you are. Silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: You going up to the Berryessa this spring, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Look out for the big rock. The smallmouth like to lay around it...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What big rock?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: You know --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You'll show me. French leans up, sees Faith at the window, she is careful to give George and French some room. French motions to George to move close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching,

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: I ought to kick your ass around the block --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (leaning in, intense) Do it, French. What are you laying around here for anyway?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: They lassoed me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well fight it, goddamit.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: I'm trying, George --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're dying on me, for Chrissake.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: intent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I need you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Thanks. French is failing badly, George kneels by French's bed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm here, French, stay with me. Faith's eyes riveted on George, who is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: {reaching out, taking George by the neck, embracing him) Okay, son. George rests his head on French's chest. French starts to breathe hard, Faith runs for the hallway. French is thrashing now, George trying to hold him down, CHARLOTTE, Faith's mother, comes rushing in, followed by NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (grabbing George) Please, please, give her some room -- A Technician enters, he and the Nurse work fast and ner- vously to get the breathing machine tubes attached. George moves closer to French.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (to George) Please, sir -- For an instant George is mangled in the tubes, French's breath becomes wildly irregular, Charlotte and Faith manage to pull George away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A damp Northern California day, the mourners walking from the grave to a row of cars with lights on. Charlotte is shepherding the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (closing a car door) . Yes, at the house -- a little lunch, soup and salad, nothing much, do come -- She moves to another car. Behind Charlotte, Faith and Sherry are about to climb into cars. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George appears, all dressed up in a nice topcoat and tie; he approaches the lead car but Charlotte blocks his path.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlotte. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Would you like me to ride with you and Faith? Faith and Sherry have come over, they each take George's arm as he faces Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: There's no room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No room or no place?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: No place.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Maybe you can squeeze in the second car with the children?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll go with Uncle Ned.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. Charlotte and Faith go.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Sherry) I forgot to get a flower. You want to come with me to get a flower? Sherry shakes her head "no." CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: LAKE BERRYESSA
dialogues.text: MOVE IN on a massive rock, a dinghy floating beside it.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DINGHY
dialogues.text: His Chesterfield still on, his hair nicely combed. A fishing rod lies untouched beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Staring into the middle distance. Fish bite in curlicues around him; he doesn't respond. Now he reaches for the oa sets them in the locks, rows into the darkness.  7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An imitation French inn, wine bottles, stone, casement windows, candlelight. For the locals, an elderly woman at a Hammond organ playing old favorites.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sitting alone, poking at a salad. From time to time, he looks up at the other guests, couples cozy at tables, lit by candles. He puts his fork down wearily, listens to the music, DOROTHY at the organ playing "Some Enchanted Eveni She sings a little.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR 118A
dialogues.text: Faith appears. The Maitre d', STEVE, hurries to her.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: One, please, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Dunlap's right over here. Faith looks over to the table where George is sitting, now points elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I would like to have that table. Steve blinks, looks over at George, now at Faith.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Certainly. Right this way.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “SOMEONE WILL BE LAUGHING

dialogues.speaker: ON GEORGE
dialogues.text: Seeing Steve show Faith to a separate table. After a moment, George signals his WAITER, then gets up and crosses to Faith.

dialogues.speaker: AT FAITH'S TABLE 118B
dialogues.text: When George appears, Steve quickly lights a candle at the table, then hurries away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (standing over Faith) What are you doing here? I thought you were staying with your mother.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I had enough of my mother. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was up at the lake.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: All this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the lake.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What were you doing up there?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Watching the bass. Bo you mind if I sit down? George sits.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are your mother's plans? What's she going to do? Is she going away -- ? The Waiter comes over, carrying plates.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to George) Did you want your food served here, sir

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE FAITH
dialogues.text: Yes. No, After a moment, the Waiter tentatively sets a plate of Scandanavian salmon down in front of George.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's not enough dill for you. George, I want to be alone. (to the Waiter) Bring him some more dill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: And for you, madam?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Nothing. I'11 eat some of his. George swallows.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why don't you order some dinner, Faith?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You mean you want me to get my own?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Good. Neither am I. The Waiter arrives with the extra sauce. George dabs at it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Here, give it to me -- She fixes the plate for him, arranging the dill and the sauce. George cuts a plece. He likes it better now.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You want a bite?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That piece in the center. She reaches over and takes it. In a moment, the two of them have devoured the salmon. Dorothy continues to play. They sit in silence,

dialogues.speaker: OUTA MY HAIR..."
dialogues.text: The Waiter appears.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Looks like we liked the Gravlax -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How about some dessert?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm on a diet -- I'm trying to lose seven pounds.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You look fine to me.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm not losing it for you. The Waiter quickly disappears. GEORGE . The waiter heard you --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't care about the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Now, Faithie --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don't 'Faithie' me, George -- it's over. All that is over. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just dismiss it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: George, you left me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You threw me out.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You left because you were screwing Sandy and everybody knew it and finally I knew it and what were you . doing spending nights in our house anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I paid the bills, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We're very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why are you putting me dom? I've worked hard -- I've worked hard -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: And I worked hard with you. You'd come off that train and I'd have the children in bed and the ice out and the scotch and the coq au vin and the pot au feu and Christ knows what else -~ and listen to your office politics and advise you and coddle you and fuck you and be up at six to get the children off and out of your way.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that right? Well I'll tell you something -- From the next table, a couple looks over, the MAN in doub knits, the WIFE, her curly hair piled precariously high.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (MAN)
dialogues.text: Hey, pipe down, buddy, we're paying for our dinner, too --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (lowering his voice) I'd come off the train and you'd always be so goddam nice and yes, you were a good cook, and yes, you were a good mother, and yes, you could lay it on for my old college friends, and yes, you were smart about elections, and you want to know something, I was in awe of you --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: In awe of me?! What the hell do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You, the children! Four children! You raised them with the back of your hand, you were so god-damned good at it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You raised them too, George --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bullshit! I was never there -- I was a bystander, an onlooker in all this... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lll. :

dialogues.speaker: 118B CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George falters,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: All this what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: . Life!I was sitting with my thumb up my ass sharpening pencils and praying some dumb editor would give me a pat on the back for a profile on the fucking greenskeeper at Pebble Beach. You were changing diapers and scraping shit off the walls but you were creating lives! And what was I doing? I was studying the fucking Bermuda grass and counting the goddam dimples on a golfball. (pauses) Don't you understand? I worshipped you.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Then for God's sake, why didn't you treat me that way? You were always yelling, George, you were always angry -- you have a terrible temper --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But you know I don't mean it --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Tell that to the children --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was afraid, don't you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid of what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I couldn't hack it. I felt Like I was swimming the English Channel with a fifty-pound weight around my neck --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That's my mother's line --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Your mother's done a lot of drowning.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Leave her out of this -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to. Your mother was a lousy mother and a lousy wife. . The Waiter returns.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Did we decide on dessert?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Tell me about Sandy, does she fuck you morning, noon and night? The Waiter disappears.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Forget about Sandy. What about him? The Redneck?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The who?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sam Stud. The character with all the cotton in his crotch. Do you do it on the backhoe?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Are you talking about Frank?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Frank! Yes, Frank! What a name! I had a counselor named Frank at sleepaway camp. Franks always love the outdoors.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: This Frank's not bad indoors.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! From the next table:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey, give us a break, will you? George reaches for his water.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You know what I love about Frank -- he's you, George -- you fifteen years ago -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- He's what I thought you might become -- what the hell happened to you, George -- Did you have to turn into such a shitheel just because you became a success? George puts the water down.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you see any good in me?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: At home -- not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why is it you're the only one I can't get along with? Everybody else loves me --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Like eating ice cream. Faith gets up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Come back here! Faith, I said come back here! From the next table:

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE, (WIFE)
dialogues.text: Come on, give him a chance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Joanne) Butt out, Bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Watch it, fella.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You watch it. pazotd reaches for George, pushes him, George pushes Haro ack.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Stop. it, George!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah, stop it, George. She'd rather fuck Frank. : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y

dialogues.speaker: 118B CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now Faith whirls on Harold,

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You asshole. Joanne jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Bitch! Faith gives Joanne the finger. Harold pushes Faith.

dialogues.speaker: . HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nobody gives Joanne the finger! Now George has grabbed Harold, he is strangling him by th shirtfront, his fury is obsessive and frightening.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Apologize to the lady.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (correcting) Woman, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Apologize to the woman. Harold tries. to shrug him off, George yanks him closer, Harold is choking. Steve, the Maitre d', scurries over.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Harold -- apologize.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: She gave you the finger --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (tightening more on Harold) You deserve it, you prick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (choking) Okay, okay -- I'm sorry... George releases Harold.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Dunlap, this is a restaurant, not a gymmasiun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you mind? I was just having a nice, quiet fight with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sit down, George, and shut up. They all sit down, Harold and Joanne edge back to their table.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How about a little brandy on the house?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Two doubles.

dialogues.speaker: , STEVE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dunlap, would you like to order?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: A lobster.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: One or two pounds?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And a little wine to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We have a new Chardonnay in -- and of course the lovely, old Gewurtztraminer --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Both. Steve looks at George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (beaming, righteous) You heard her, both. Steve goes off in a daze. George looks over at Harold, waggles his fingers provokingly. Faith giggles uncon- scionably. Harold and Joanne get up and leave ostentatiou George and Faith are served their brandies. George lifts his glass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think we won. Faith lifts her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we, George? GO OUT on Faith's face as they touch glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors lining the hall. GIGGLES from the far end of the hall, George and Faith making their way down; they are both a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (whispering) How do you feel about the Gewurtztraminer?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: The Gewurtztrawho? : ’ GEORGE The Gewurtztraminer.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: A trifle authoritarian,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And just the least bit Lufthansa. After a moment;

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Where are the children? Faith stops at a door.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Next door. George looks at the next door, now at this door.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh. (after a moment) Well... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Faith smiles gently.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Good night, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good night. : Faith hugs him. He tries to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don't, George, please -- She tries to guide him away.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where's your room, George? He starts searching in his pockets, tries them all, final finds a key.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: One-eleven.

dialogues.speaker: FAITE
dialogues.text: Okay, one-eleven. Faith looks around at the doors, sees one-eleven.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: George, that's my room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, it's my room.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean it's your room, it’s my room. One-eleven is my room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The clerk assigned me to one-eleven when I checked in. There appears to be some misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Get yourself another room, George. She opens the door, turns her back on George. George crowds right in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is my room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Well you're not sleeping in here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Half of this room is mine. He pushes right past her and falls through the door. She grabs him just in time, props him upright. He moves towards her, reaches for her and kisses her. She responds gently. Now she pulls him to her. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two faces, George and Faith, side-by-side. PULL BACK to see George and Faith in bed, Faith's face flushed and damp, George's hair tousled. Faith's hand is against her face, George reaches to touch her hand, she turns her face away.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: This was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What was crazy?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Me. Here. With you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Because we're not together.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're here, aren't we? a (CONT ENUED)  120

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. i19. 120

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don't know. Call it a weak moment, call it anything you want --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it? FAITH . My father died and then I wanted you ~- and then I see tomorrow -- you playing one-on-one with Sandy's son -- you with Sandy, she with you --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't -- please stop --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I was never right for you, George -- I sang all the music but I never knew the words --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You knew the words -- you were a good mother --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: . But I forgot how to be a good wife. Oh jee-zus I loved you, George, jee-zus God I loved you. I loved you because you could love. You made me feel loved when I was a girl and you helped me grow into a woman. And just now, for an instant there -- I don't know -- you made me laugh, George -- you were kind.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're right, I'm not kind anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're kind to strangers.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Strangers are easy. A KNOCK at the door. George gets up, opens it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sherry is there. She looks at Faith, then at George. Faith sits up straight.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Molly threw up her eclair.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'il be right there. I think you better leave, George. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: All confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights strung up on the wire mesh fence surrounding the completed court. The new clay surface reflects the light. Added to that, torches burning in all corners. A few locals: Rick, Frank's partner, plus other couples, presentable and not-so-presentable; on the court, Mariann and Molly and Jill lob balls to each other. At the open end of the court, in the summer house, a barbecue pit, Frank firing up some steaks. A CASSETTE PLAYER is hooked up to a couple of speakers; a few people dance desultorily. .

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY 122
dialogues.text: All bubbly and smiling, watching Frank work. He salts the steaks, puts them aside prior to firing them. Faith comes out of the house carrying pitchers of beer.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Would you like to dance, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: In a minute, Sherry. Let me just get these steaks on. Faith places the beer on a table, looking pleased.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Lots of salt -- I fike them all black and crusty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got it, lady. Frank spreads on:the salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party ablaze with light, the court glistening, the summer house casting pleasant shadows, the PLOP of TENNIS BALLS mixing with slow DANCE MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH AND FRANK
dialogues.text: Frank takes Frank's hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: This is it exactly. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You like to dance?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why not? He turns to Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Watch the steaks, will you, Sher? Give them five minutes, then flip them. He hands her a big fork.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH AND FRANK
dialogues.text: Dancing, not much space between them.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Watching. The CASSETTE finishes, In the silence, Sherry flips the steaks.

dialogues.speaker: ON RICK
dialogues.text: Pulling a guitar from a case. He strums. Frank and Faith return to Sherry to survey the steaks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . FRANK
dialogues.text: Lookin' good, Sher. Sherry hands Frank back the fork. Rick's guitar plays in the background.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Rick's not bad, huh, Sher?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Not bad at all.

dialogues.speaker: FAITE
dialogues.text: Go get your guitar. Sherry. You and Rick could play together.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I'm not good enough. Frank pokes her with the fork.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Sher. She starts back for the house. Frank and Faith move back to the tennis court, dancing close again.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Pausing in the doorway, looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, Frank and Faith tied together, Frank's hands running over Faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherry grabbing for her guitar. As she passes Faith's bedroom, she stops. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Faith's bed, a big canvas bag. Spilling out, a man's jeans and T-shirts, work boots. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bag. CUT To:  123.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TENNIS COURT
dialogues.text: Molly, Jill and Marianne have disappeared. Piles of plate and discarded steak bones. Couples paired off. Rick is still playing.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH AND SHERRY AND FRANK 125
dialogues.text: The three of them dancing together, arms wrapped around each other. They seem dreamy and happy.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Frank spending the night?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Just tonight. He brought his toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: That's a big bag for a toothbrush. Faith stops dancing.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Sherry?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: I mean I saw Frank's bag. It looks like he's going to stay awhile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't go jumping to any conclusions, Sherry,

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: (to Faith) Am I jumping?

dialogues.speaker: . FAITH
dialogues.text: It's none of your business --

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You fuck Daddy last week. You fuck Frank this week. Who you going to fuck next week? Faith slaps Sherry across the face, a terrible shot, her cheek flarés, Sherry blinks her eye, she starts to waver. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The blood rushes to her face, she runs away.

dialogues.speaker: . FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry! Sherry!

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Sprinting. Frank and Faith start after her.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY 126
dialogues.text: Too fast for them. Ina moment, she has disappeared into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: Stumbling, grabbing --

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Sherry! Sherry, honey, where are you? SHER-REE!!

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERRY
dialogues.text: Still going, lights receding behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAITH
dialogues.text: She dives into the woods, runs down a trail. But she has lost Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, George and Sandy and Timmy playing ca PAN away from the window to the bushes; movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card game inside, laughter, smiles on everybody's aces,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy scooping up the cards.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: One more hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ssh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 on i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. George pauses, listens attentively, goes to the French doors and opens them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down at the pier beside the water, Sherry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: ON TIMMY AND SANDY
dialogues.text: Watching George run down the steps toward the beach.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PIER 129
dialogues.text: Sherry sitting, the light hitting the bay on this warm night, the water slapping, a dinghy bumping against the pilings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George appears, typewriter in hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought it was you. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Nothing --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You took a walk?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: By mistake. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I brought you your birthday present. He hands her the typewriter. She looks at it suspiciously

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It has all the letters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sherry opens it.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Is it electric? I hate electric. She lifts the canvas cover, moonlight reflects off chrome and keys. Sherry stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: It's not electric. Have you got any paper? He starts to reach for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Never mind. Sherry pokes in her pocket, pulls out an old candy wrappe rolls it into the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You want to come inside? Sherry makes a face. She stares back at the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: It's not dinky at all. She plunks something out. George smiles. Sherry closes the case. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You slept with Mommy up at Grandpa's.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You fuck Sandy and then you fuck Mommy . GEORGE . Please --

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Please, what? -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think I have to take that from you.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You haven't much choice. ‘

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh I don't? -- well I can just leave your little ass to freeze down here -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: Good. George starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (turning around Honey, please. -

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: My ‘Little ass' has not frozen yet...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Please, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRY
dialogues.text: You're always sorry. I just don't want to get zapped with a hanger again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Never. George leans over her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
